Acting ICE director removed amid White House pressure to boost arrests The Trump administration has removed the top official at Immigration and Customs Enforcement one month into his tenure, as White House officials have become increasingly frustrated that the agency isn’t arresting immigrants fast enough to satisfy the president’s deportation goals. Caleb Vitello, a veteran ICE official who was installed as acting director when President Donald Trump took office, will be reassigned to a senior role overseeing daily enforcement operations, according to Department of Homeland Security spokeswoman Tricia McLaughlin. She did not say who would replace him. Trump has ordered ICE to carry out the largest mass deportation campaign in U.S. history and quickly ramp up the number of immigrants it arrests each day. Despite the administration dedicating a rush of resources to the effort that has included sending thousands of troops to the southern border and assigning thousands of agents and officers from the FBI and other federal law enforcement agencies, ICE’s budget and staffing remain largely unchanged, leaving officers scrambling to meet aggressive arrest quotas. In late January, Vitello told ICE’s 25 field office directors they should arrest at least 75 immigrants per day for a national daily total of 1,200 to 1,500. ICE officers have been working six and even seven days a week since then, but Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi L. Noem and Trump “border czar” Tom Homan have blamed agency officials for falling far short of those goals. Homan did not respond to requests for comment. Louisiana Secretary of Wildlife and Fisheries Madison Sheahan, a former campaign aide to Noem, is expected to become acting deputy director of ICE, according to two people familiar with the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss a position that hadn’t been publicly announced. Sheahan was also executive director of the South Dakota GOP. A DHS official said that “positions are being reevaluated” and that the agency had “nothing new to announce at this time.” ICE averaged more than 800 arrests per day nationwide in late January in the 10 days after Trump took office, publishing its results on social media amid a publicity campaign that invited television crews to embed with officers. The pace of arrests slowed during the first two weeks of February to fewer than 600 daily, and ICE stopped publishing data on social media, saying it would move to a monthly format. Current and former ICE officials said the enforcement blitz in late January depleted the lists of targets ICE developed before Trump took office with the names, addresses and other data on immigrants they could arrest. Officer teams have not had time to build out new target lists. Officers have also struggled to meet their quotas because many immigrants are refusing to open their doors when ICE officers knock, according to three ICE officials. Noem has accused FBI agents of leaking sensitive information about upcoming immigration enforcement operations, which the law enforcement agency has pushed back on. The enforcement teams generally do not possess criminal arrest warrants that would allow them to force their way into their targets’ residences. ICE officials say they can’t afford to leave teams of officers waiting for targeted immigrants to leave their homes. Vitello’s demotion follows the reassignment this month of the top two officials at ICE’s enforcement division. A Trump administration official said that Vitello will now oversee field and enforcement operations as part of an effort to expand the team. The official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the personnel move, said Noem made the decision and it was not done at Trump’s direction. Vitello’s removal was first reported Friday by The Wall Street Journal. Several ICE staffers said news of his demotion caught them by surprise, and they found out through news alerts. Jason Houser, chief of staff for ICE under President Joe Biden, said that the White House is asking ICE to “defy the math” and do things that are “unrealistic.” “The White House needs to look in the mirror,” Houser said. “The dysfunction isn’t with ICE rank-and-file who are trying to do their jobs effectively.” The Trump administration has sought to take an all-of-government approach to immigration enforcement, treating it as a near wartime effort. At least 3,600 servicemen and servicewomen have been sent to the border, according to the Defense Department. The administration has used military planes to transport migrants to locations as far away as India. As ICE has run out of space in its detention centers, the Trump administration has started to send migrants to the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba, where Trump ordered the construction of a detention camp with 30,000 beds. On Thursday, 177 Venezuelan migrants at Guantánamo were deported to their homeland. Homan has said he is “not happy” with the results so far. Senate Budget Committee Chair Lindsey Graham (R-South Carolina) said recently that Homan came to the Hill “begging” for additional money. The Senate adopted a budget blueprint early Friday for legislation to increase border security and immigration enforcement by $175 billion. Trump has backed a competing, more expansive plan in the House. The Biden administration deported 271,000 people in fiscal year 2024, the highest annual total in a decade. Deportations during Trump’s first term reached a peak of about 267,000 during the 2019 fiscal year, even as he made similar promises. ICE would need to deport more than 2,700 people a day to hit 1 million deportations a year, a goal that veteran immigration officials say is improbable.
